original: Borgström, Karl Marcus, lektor, Linköping, f. 8/12/82 i Ardala, Södermani. 1., av G. A. B. o. Christina Pettersson. G. 39 m. Hedvig Setterholm. — Mog:ex. i Malmö o. folksk :lär :ex. i Strängnäs 05, fil. kand. i Upps. 08, fil. lic. 12, fil. dr 13, provår i Sthlm 09-10. Res. t. Norge, ^Danm., Finl., Engl., Tyskl, Schweiz, Österr. o. Ital. Vik. folksk :lär. i Jättendal 04, vik. lektor v. sjökrigssk. 09, e. lär. i Upps. 10-11, adj. v. Strängnäs folkskisem. 11, lektor i modersm., psyk. o. pedag. d<är 18 t. sem. nedlägg. 32, däreft. v. Linköp. folkskisem. Bibi. i Strängnäs 14-30 o. vik. rektor 21, 22 o. 30-32, vik. folksk :insp. i Uppl. s. distr. 16. Var i Strängnäs bl. a. v. ordf. i stads-fullm., ordf. i beredn lutsk. o. drätsel-kamm. Skr.: Askersmålets ljudlära (grad-.avh. 13), Sv. språkets hist. (4 uppl. 32) m. m. RNO.
translated: Borgström, Karl Marcus, lecturer, Linköping, born December 8th, 1882 in Ardala, Södermani. First child of G.A.B. and Christina Pettersson. Married in 1939 to Hedvig Setterholm. Completed his primary school teacher exam in Malmö and his teaching degree in Strängnäs in 1905. Received a BA in Uppsala in 1908, a master's degree in 1912, and a PhD in 1913, and did his probationary year in Stockholm from 1909-1910. Traveled to Norway, Denmark, Finland, England, Germany, Switzerland, Austria, and Italy. Held positions as a substitute primary school teacher in Jättendal in 1904, substitute lecturer at the naval academy in 1909, a teacher in Uppsala from 1910-1911, an adjunct teacher at Strängnäs folk high school in 1911, and a lecturer in mother tongue, psychology, and pedagogy until the end of 1932. Thereafter, he worked at the Linköping folk high school. He was a librarian in Strängnäs from 1914-1930 and was a substitute principal in 1921, 1922, and 1930-1932, and a substitute primary school inspector in Upplands South District in 1916. He served as vice-chairman of the city council and chairman of the committee on education and the finance committee in Strängnäs. Authored "The Phonetics of the Askersmålet Dialect" (degree paper, 1913), "The History of the Swedish Language" (4th edition, 1932), and other books. He was awarded the Order of the North Star.
